title: Wildbook takes over Bing’s homepage for a day | Department of Computer Science | University of Illinois at Chicago

Department of Computer Science     Search the site     Toggle Menu      Search                  Department of Computer Science      Department of Computer Science   Main Menu    Undergraduate           Admitted Students    Admissions    Accreditation    CS Major    CS Minor    Courses    Internships and Jobs    Student Groups    Student Profiles    Student Resources    Women in CS         Graduate           Admitted Students    Admissions    Courses    MS Program    PhD Program    PhD Dissertations    Post-Graduation Outcomes    Student Profiles    Student Resources         Research           Research Areas    Labs    Lectures and Seminars    Research Experiences for Undergraduates         Faculty and Staff           Department Head    Faculty    Emeritus Faculty    Adjunct Faculty    Staff    Faculty Resources    Open Positions         News           News Stories    Press Mentions         Events           CS calendar    Student Opportunities          Eyebrow menu    Break Through Tech    Giving    Alumni    UIC Engineering Home    UIC menu    UIC.edu    Campus Map       Search                     Wildbook takes over Bing’s homepage for a day    Posted on August 15, 2018         main text      Professor Tanya Berger-Wolf’s Wildbook project was featured on the Bing search engine homepage on August 14th.  The homepage featured the endangered Grevy’s zebra, an animal whose population Wildbook has aimed to help conserve using AI and crowd-sourced photography. Wildbook is a part of Wild Me , an established non-profit that Berger-Wolf oversees with her team of conservation enthusiasts. The group has helped take a more accurate census of thousands of endangered species, including giraffes, elephants, and whale sharks, among others.  In addition to the featured image, Bing hosted a three-question quiz for users to test their zebra knowledge. Wildbook’s collaboration with Bing stems from its relationship with parent company Microsoft.  Microsoft recently announced Wild Me as one of their five featured projects for its AI for Earth initiative, which includes a $50 million commitment toward utilizing AI to help protect the planet and its inhabitants.      Modified on December 17, 2019
